newsitem.title: USA: Clinton seeks Hill-White House task force on D.C..
newsitem.headline: Clinton seeks Hill-White House task force on D.C..

text.p: President Clinton and Congressional leaders agreed to launch a joint task force of administration, Capitol Hill and District of Columbia leaders to seek solutions to D.C.'s mounting education, crime and taxpayer flight problems, Hill leaders said on Tuesday.

House of Representatives Speaker Newt Gingrich and Senate Majority Leader Trent Lott announced the plan at a press briefing following a meeting between Clinton and bipartisan Congressional leaders on top government priorities.
"The President said why don't you and the Speaker indicate a couple of point people from your operation and meet with us and representatives of D.C.," said Lott, R-Miss.
"We didn't say let's do this tax proposal or that spending measure or this crime action," Lott said. "We said it's serious and we need to focus on it, we need to set up a process."

Gingrich, R-Ga., said, "I thought (Clinton's) proposal today that we put together a joint executive-legislative tax force, that we work together in a quiet way, and that we take seriously how do we get to measurable improvement in the quality of life of young people (in D.C.)...is very positive."
Lott said he knows that some members of Congress oppose an infusion of funds for the District.
"Some will say, wait, we're not going to do that in D.C. if we're not going to do that in my cities," Lott said.

"Our argument is this is the nation's capital. There is a crisis here," Lott said. "We ought to try somthing -- maybe even experiment. If it works here, maybe we can take it to the rest of the country, state by state."
Gingrich said, "There's a definable, doable challenge and one that the rest of the country can draw strength from and learn from."
Lott said Hill leaders and the President did not discuss specific solutions.

"(But) we believe there are some things we can agree on," he said. He noted that he and Gingrich support a controversial proposal by D.C.'s delegate to Congress, Eleanor Holmes Norton, for a D.C. flat tax.
Lott said he and Gingrich are "very concerned" about D.C. crime and how D.C.'s children are "locked into" unworkable schools.

Lott said he met with D.C. Mayor Marion Barry on Monday and Barry wanted to know what Congress can do about mounting crime. "I said, Mr. Mayor, anything, something, everything. We have got to deal with these problems," Lott said.
Gingrich said Hill leaderse and Clinton did not discuss if the death penalty should be imposed in D.C. "I don't think we are in a position to comment on that."
